repnme.cdata!:
Mali - The National Agricultural Research
            Project (NARP), the Agricultural Trading and Processing
            Promotion Pilot Project (ATPPP), and the Pilot Private
            Irrigation Promotion Project (PPP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the National
            Agricultural Research Project (NARP) of Mali were as
            follows: outcome was satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory; and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. The ratings for the Agricultural Trading and
            Processing Promotion Pilot Project (ATPPP) of Mali were as
            follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was significant; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and Borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. The ratings for the Pilot Private Irrigation
            Promotion Project (PPP) of Mali were as follows: outcome was
            highly satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            significant; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and Borrower performance was highly unsatisfactory. Several
            lessons of both a substantive and procedural nature have
            emerged from this review: (1) Meeting the challenge of
            pro-poor agricultural growth requires addressing a number of
            institutional constraints that farmers in Mali face in
            relation to rural finance, land titling, and the provision
            of public services such as wholesale market facilities; (2)
            Ambitious and unrealistic development objectives and project
            design complicate implementation and supervision; (3)
            Effective stakeholder representation in decision making and
            in validating results is important to the success of
            public-private partnerships; (4) Overestimating the
            readiness of the Borrower to implement a project leads to
            unavoidable implementation delays and costly changes in
            project design; and (5) For projects supporting private
            sector development, implementing agencies need to have a
            results-oriented culture and should sub-contract the
            management and implementation of certain activities to
            private service providers, including NGOs.

repnme.cdata!:
Mali - Agricultural Trading and Processing
            Promotion Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is overall satisfactory.
            The sustainability of the PAVCOPA project will probably vary
            depending on the category of beneficiary. The increasing
            professionalism of producers, processors and traders and
            their involvement in the associative movement will probably
            have lasting effects, since it has increased their revenues
            and helped them to become operational within Mali's
            administrative and legal environment. The sustainability of
            the vitality that the project injected into the Chambers of
            Agriculture cannot yet be assessed. The Bank's overall
            performance is rated marginally satisfactory. The Bank
            recognized implementation errors by the executing agency and
            took responsibility for addressing the shortcomings. As a
            result, the project staff was replaced in 2001 and a new
            implementation plan prepared and launched at a workshop in
            Selingue. That workshop produced, within a coherent
            operational plan, a logframe for the project that was
            intended to make up for the absence of such a document at
            the time of project appraisal. The Bank also dealt firmly
            with deficiencies noted in financial management in December
            2002 by writing two successive letters to the Minister of
            Finance requesting corrective action. However, the Bank was
            slow to take action to correct monitoring and evaluation
            deficiencies, and to suggest the organizational and
            institutional reforms needed to spur project activities. The
            overall performance of the Borrower is rated unsatisfactory
            (U). Although there was consistent commitment to the project
            despite high turnover of government personnel and project
            staff, several recommendations from supervision missions
            were not implemented, and issues of monitoring and
            evaluation, financial management and institutional
            arrangements, although clearly identified, were not
            addressed effectively or in a timely manner. This project
            demonstrated the importance of beneficiary involvement in
            monitoring and evaluation. In particular, beneficiaries who
            contribute to project activities in cash or in kind should
            be involved in the planning and execution of those
            activities. Stakeholder participation and consensus-building
            are essential to a public-private partnership program.
            Stakeholders must be engaged early in the process, and then
            kept informed, in order to ensure sustainability and
            effective ownership. Other lessons pertained to the need to
            carefully select project implementation staff, who are
            business-oriented as well as technically competent; the need
            to have an independent body closely monitor the project,
            while striking a balance in this case, between Executing
            Agency control and autonomy; and the need for the Bank to
            react decisively to important recommendations from
            supervision missions, followed up by Government action.
            Lessons for the formulation of agribusiness projects were
            also detailed.

repnme.cdata!:
Mali - Agricultural Trading and Processing
            Promotion Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Trading and Processing
            Promotion Pilot project is a five year project that will
            address key sectoral constraints to private investment in
            agricultural processing and marketing, and will focus
            primarily on capacity-building and on the transfer of
            know-how to the private sector through information networks,
            training, specialized technical assistance, and study tours.
            The project will pursue a two pronged approach: (a)
            provision of generic support in three regions to all
            profitable agroprocessing private entrepreneurs, upstream
            and downstream of agricultural production, and (b) transfer
            of specialized expertise to enterprises operating in
            subsectors or product lines with a high potential for
            international export which require high-quality standards,
            such as fresh and dried fruits and vegetables, hides and
            skins, and shea nuts and other exotic products. Project
            management will be entrusted to an "Agricultural
            Trading and Processing Promotion Agency". The
            Government will exercise overall project supervision through
            the Ministry of Rural Development and Environment. The
            Agency will have streamlined operating structures,
            comprising a coordinating unit located in Bamako, and, in
            full operation, three regional support units. The project
            will provide funding for: (i) the operating of the
            Agency's three regional branches in the Sikasso, Segou,
            and Mopti regions; (ii) support packages, including
            specialized technical assistance, training, studies and
            investment funds for three professional organizations
            promoting vertical integration for the fruit/vegetable,
            hide/skins, and oilseeds/shea nut subsectors; (iii) the
            Agency's operations and management, and the
            establishment and operation of an agricultural processing
            and marketing information exchange network; and (iv)
            activities aimed at facilitating entrepreneurs' access
            to investment financing and credit.
